content.content: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns.

A calendar is not a matrix because it has rows and columns that are not complete. In this course we will write our matrices with round brackets around the numbers. Elsewhere, square brackets are often used.

Opening Problem: Gerty has invested in real estate. She owns a block of 10 apartments, 5 units, and 3 houses. She wishes to put new furniture in each of them. In each apartment she puts 4 chairs, 1 table and 2 beds. In each unit she puts 6 chairs, 1 table and 3 beds. In each house she puts 8 chairs, 2 tables and 4 beds. If each chair costs 35 euros, each table 175 euros and each bed 235 euros, how much will the furniture cost in total?

One way to solve the Opening Problem is to use a matrix, or rectangular array of numbers. You have been using matrices for many years without realising it. For example, you may have used them to display your school results.
The information in the Opening Problem can be summarised in tables: Furniture Prices and Furniture Inventory.
We could also write the information in detailed matrix form. Provided we can remember what each row and column stands for, we can omit the labels.
latex: \begin{pmatrix} 35 \\ 175 \\ 235 \end{pmatrix} \text{ has 3 rows and 1 column and we say that this is a } 3 \times 1 \text{ column matrix or column vector.}
\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix} \text{ has 1 row and 4 columns and is called a } 1 \times 4 \text{ row matrix or row vector.}
\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 1 & 2 \\ 6 & 1 & 3 \\ 8 & 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix} \text{ has 3 rows and 3 columns and is called a } 3 \times 3 \text{ square matrix.}
\text{An } m \times n \text{ matrix has } m \text{ rows and } n \text{ columns.}
\text{The numbers in the matrix are called its elements.}
m \times n \text{ is called the order of the matrix.}

content.content: Two matrices are equal if and only if: the matrices have the same shape or order, and elements in corresponding positions are equal.
content.latex: \text{For example, if } \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}, \text{ then } a = 2, b = 1, c = 3, \text{ and } d = 5.

content.content: Find j, k, l and m.
content.latex: \text{If } \begin{pmatrix} j & k+1 \\ 2l & m \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 6 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \text{ find } j, k, l \text{ and } m.
content.solution: \text{Since the matrices are equal, } j = 2, k+1 = -1, 2l = 6, m = 0 \\ \therefore j = 2, k = -2, l = 3, \text{ and } m = 0

latex: \text{We can represent this information by using a quantities matrix } \mathbf{Q} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}
\text{The total cost at the newsagent is } (3 \times 0.60 + 2 \times 1.20 + 1 \times 2.30) = \pounds 6.50.
\text{The total cost at the supermarket is } (3 \times 0.45 + 2 \times 1.10 + 1 \times 2.50) = \pounds 6.05.

content.content: Matrix multiplication has a different meaning to that used for multiplying numbers. In this case we multiply each element of a row by the corresponding element of a column, and then add the results.
latex: \text{If matrix } \mathbf{A} \text{ is } m \times n \text{ and matrix } \mathbf{B} \text{ is } n \times p \text{ then their product } \mathbf{AB} \text{ exists and is an } m \times p \text{ matrix.}
\text{We multiply each member of a row in } \mathbf{A} \text{ by each member of a column of } \mathbf{B} \text{ and add the results.}
\text{If the number of columns in } \mathbf{A} \text{ does not equal the number of rows in } \mathbf{B}, \text{ then } \mathbf{AB} \text{ does not exist.}
